## Burgenland

Austriaâ€™s second-largest wine region after Lower Austria, Burgenland (13,840 acres/5,600 hectares) huddles against Hungary on the far eastern border (Budapest is only some 130 miles/210 kilometers away). The vineyards here, along with those in Hungary, formed a vast, uninterrupted sea of vines during the Austro-Hungarian monarchy. Burgenland is known primarily for its opulent sweet wines, as well as some remarkable reds.

Sweet wines have been the glory of this part of central Europe for eons. The most celebrated typeâ€”_ausbruch_â€”is made mostly from grapes infected by _Botrytis cinerea_, although some of the grapes can simply be dried and shriveled. For _ausbruch_, these grapes are then mixed with freshly pressed must from grapes that are only partially botrytized. (Reflecting Burgenlandâ€™s proximity to Hungary, this process is similar to the manner in which Hungaryâ€™s famous sweet wine, Tokaji AszÃº, is made; see page 632.) Both the fully and partially botrytized grapes for _ausbruch_ must come from the same vineyard. The grapes are sometimes foot-trodden, and the wine is aged in casks. _Ausbruch_ is more baroque, outrageous, brulÃ©ed, and honeyed than _beerenauslese_, but has less residual sugar and more alcohol than _trockenbeerenauslese_.

The most famous _ausbruch_ etc., as well as BAs and TBAs, are made possible by a hauntingly beautiful natural entity: an almost supernatural lake poised between northern Burgenland and Hungary named Neusiedl (the Austrians call this the Neusiedlersee). More than 186 square miles (482 square kilometers) in size, it is only 2 to 7 feet (0.6 to 2 meters) deep. The shallow lake gives up so much humidity that it is threatened by constant evaporation. In fact, twice during the past century it dried up completely. Reeds and grasses love the lake. So many of them grow around it that thatching material developed into a local industry. Birds also love the lake. Indeed, the vast bird population has resulted in the area becoming one of Europeâ€™s largest wildlife preserves. And thanks to the thousands of storks that nest and feed here, the lake has been called a stork smorgasbord. But as much as the reeds or the birds, grapes love the lake. Itâ€™s where they love to rot.

### Graters
- **Usage**: For grating ingredients over a drink.
- **Details**:
  - Freshly grated cinnamon and nutmeg offer superior taste compared to preground versions.
  - Handheld kitchen graters are ideal for grating hard cheese, spices like cinnamon and nutmeg, and dark chocolate.
  - A coarse Microplane grater is specifically recommended for grating dark chocolate.

### Vegetable Peelers
- **Usage**: For preparing citrus peels.
- **Details**:
  - A strategy for citrus garnishes involves the use of a vegetable peeler to avoid the bitter white pith beneath the zest.
  - A heavy-duty, Y-shaped peeler with a sharp, nonserrated blade is ideal, like those offered by Oxo with a nonslip rubber handle.
  - Plastic peelers are not recommended, as they are less durable and the blades may detach unexpectedly.

3. **Outcome Variabilities:**

**Title:** Old World/New World: Differences in Philosophy and Flavor

**Author:** Randall Grahm  
**Title:** Winemaker

---

**Text:**

"It may sound dated to speak of Old World and New World, but such terms do describe a wine concept of up-to-the-minute relevance. They are particularly useful when explaining the differences in both wine styles among producers and wine tastes among consumers. The winemaking style of classic Old World regions, including France and Italy, is rooted in centuries of tradition and emphasizes distinctiveness, or typicity. Terroir is the term used to describe the individuality of a given site for grapes, its flavor fingerprint independent of the stylistic inputs of the winemaker. The Old World is, or at least once was, more focused on celebrating the special characteristics inherent in each vineyard, whether the soil types that impart unique flavor characteristics or the distinctive differences among vintages. New World regions such as the United States and Chile, by contrast, are pioneering an approach that relies more on technological innovation and stylized winemaking formulas to achieve commercial acceptance. The newcomers are most comfortable in the position of control, from irrigation of the vineyards to cultured strains of yeast. This approach leaves little to chance, trusting in better living through wine chemistry."

---

**Author Info:**

Randall Grahm is the founder and fearless leader of Bonny Doon Vineyard and one of Californiaâ€™s most eccentric and influential vintners. Like Columbus seeking a trade route to Asia, Grahm set sail in 1979 for the Great American Pinot Noir, foundered on the shoals of astringency and finesselessness, and ended up running aground in the utterly unexpected New World of RhÃ´ne and Italian grape varieties. A citizen of the world, he is perhaps best known as a champion of the strange and the heterodox, of the ugly duckling grape varieties whose very existence is threatened by the dominant Cabo- and Chardo-centric paradigms.

# Wine Terminology

## B
### BUD
- **Description**: The small node on a grapevine shoot that carries within it the grape clusters for the year to come, allowing tiny clusters and shoots to emerge.

### BUDDING
- **Description**: The act of grafting buds of one vine onto an existing planted vine, known as "field budding."

### BULK PROCESS
- **Description**: An inexpensive and quick method of making sparkling wine using the Charmat method, involving large, pressurized tanks for secondary fermentation, alternative to the MÃ©thode Champenoise.

### BULK WINE
- **Description**: Wine not in bottles, sold in large quantities by wineries of all sizes. Prices may increase when the crop size is reduced.

### BUNG
- **Description**: A plug used for stopping a wine barrel.

### BUSHVINE
- **Description**: A vine that is free-standing with no trellis system, appearing bush-like.

### BUTTERY
- **Description**: A descriptor for wine aromas and flavors reminiscent of butter, created by diacetyl, a by-product of malolactic fermentation.

## C
### CANE
- **Description**: A shoot that hardens and turns tannish brown in the fall, historically pruned back during winter.

### CANE TRAINING
- **Description**: The process of training a vine along a structure such as a trellis.

### CANOPY
- **Description**: The top of the vine where leaves and shoots form, resembling an umbrella.

### CAP
- **Description**: A foam or layer of grape skins, pulp, stems, and seeds that is pushed down during red wine fermentation to extract color, aroma, flavor, and tannins from the grape materials.

### CAPSULE
- **Description**: A sheath placed over the cork and top part of a wine bottleâ€™s neck, traditionally made from lead but now uses safer materials. Helps in pest control and health protection.

### CARBON DIOXIDE
- **Description**: A by-product of fermentation, influencing the fizziness in wines when trapped inside a closed vessel.

### CARBONIC MACERATION
- **Description**: A fermentation method where grapes are fermented whole in a closed tank, releasing juice that ferments inside, typically used to make fruity, less tannic wines like those from Beaujolais.

### CARTOUCHE
- **Description**: An emblem or logo usually found on wine bottles from ChÃ¢teauneuf-du-Pape, often reflecting historical or royal symbols.

The text starts by explaining the careful monitoring required during the fermentation of koji, particularly when dealing with soybeans due to their high protein content. Fermentation temperatures above 95Â°F/35Â°C make the soybeans highly susceptible to Bacillus subtilis. While soybeans don't smell as sweet as when combined with roasted wheat, they still produce a pleasant aroma.

#### **Reference to Related Content**

The text mentions a reference to "Soy Sauce in chapter 11" where the reader can find additional information related to the subject.

#### **Propagation of Koji Starter (Tane Koji)**

The process of propagating koji starter, using brown rice (referred to as "seed koji"), is outlined. White rice isn't used because it lacks essential nutrients required for optimal mold growth. 

- **Preparation of Rice:** The brown rice should be soaked, drained, steamed, and cooled. 
- **Inoculation:** Hardwood ashes are mixed in (about 1.5% by weight of the rice) to provide potassium, magnesium, and other nutrients. Then the rice is inoculated.
- **Fermentation:** The inoculated mixture is incubated at approximately 79Â°F/26Â°C, initially for 24 hours. It's then remounted for another 24 hours, and after 48 hours, spread onto cotton and left undisturbed to encourage mold growth.
- **Drying and Storage:** After a total of 96 hours and visible growth, the koji is dried in an oven or dehydrator at about 113Â°F/45Â°C and stored in a cool, dark place.
  
#### **Utilization**

The dried starter can be used whole, ground into meal, or further processed to extract spores. Mixing with flour is also suggested, particularly for miso production.

#### **Reference Work**

The process described is sourced from Shurtleff and Aoyagi's book "Miso Production," which further elaborates on the topic in a dedicated chapter.

- Bordeaux features about **400 trading houses**, playing a critical role in the region's wine market for about a century.

**Intermediaries and Market Reach:**
- Around **130 courtiers** (brokers) facilitate interactions between producers and trading houses, covering distribution channels that handle two-thirds of production within France, with the remaining third exported (two-thirds of these exports go to EU countries).

- The region is divided into **60 appellations of controlled origin**.

### BORN TO RHÃ”NE

**Randall Grahm and Bonny Doon Vineyard**
Randall Grahm, the owner of Bonny Doon Vineyard, is an MIT-educated intellectual from the mid-eighties. Grahm was initially known for his innovative approach in winemaking at Bonny Doon, located in Santa Cruz. He is recognized for his idiosyncratic wines and unique methods of showcasing them, such as suspending Bonny Doon's flying machine from the ceiling of the tasting room.

**A Shift to RhÃ´ne Varieties**
During the 1970s in Los Angeles, Grahm started as a wine shop sales clerk and later founded Bonny Doon with financial support from his family. Grahm's turning point came within a decade when he embraced RhÃ´ne varieties, particularly syrah, grenache, marsanne, and roussanne. His first notable success was Cigare Volant, a style inspired by French RhÃ´ne wines. This wine catapulted him to fame and he began producing many successful varieties, which had been largely overlooked by other California winemakers at the time.

**Other Notable Wineries in Monterey**
- **David Bruce Winery**: Known for its pinot noirs, this winery embraces variations that range from great to eccentric, building a cult following.
- **Mount Eden Vineyards**: Famous for its estate chardonnays, which were first planted in 1948 on a mountain crest in Monterey.

**Monterey County Wine Region**
Monterey County is the largest appellation in the northern part of the Central Coast, spanning about 40,000 acres of vines. This region, known for its fertile Salinas Valley, is dubbed the "lettuce capital of the world" and produces over 50 percent of the U.S. vegetables including broccoli, strawberries, mushrooms, spinach, artichokes, and chili peppers.

Monterey's wine recognition only emerged in the 1960s and 1970s post extensive urban development in cities like San Jose and Santa Clara, which pushed vineyard investments southward due to soaring land prices in areas like Sonoma and Napa.

The climate of southern Monterey can be extremely hot, but the northern part benefits from chilly tunnel winds from the northern Pacific, crucial for cooling the coastal vineyards and promoting slow grape ripening. However, severe winds can inhibit photosynthesis by causing the bushes to shut down, which poses a challenge in an already cool climate region.

The document provides insights into two notable aspects of wines, specifically focusing on Riesling and Sangiovese. Here's a structured content representation:

### Riesling Wine Characteristics
- **General Profile**: Rieslings from cooler climates, like Clare and Eden valleys in Australia, are typically vibrant and fresh, known as "tightrope" wines due to their balanced nature. In comparison, Rieslings from warmer regions, such as California, tend to be softer and less precise in their mineral flavors.
- **Misconceptions on Sweetness**:
  - **Common Assumption**: People often expect Riesling to be sweet.
  - **Reality**: Most Rieslings globally are dry, with the exception of intentionally sweet styles like Beerenauslese (BA) and Trockenbeerenauslese (TBA).
- **Sweetness Determination**: The International Riesling Foundation (IRF) has developed a Riesling Taste Profile chart to assist in pinpointing whether a Riesling is sweet or dry based on technical guidelines such as sugar-to-acid ratio and the pH of the wine.

### Sangiovese Wine Characteristics
- **Regions**:
  - **Primary**: Central Italy, specifically Tuscany (notable for Chianti Classico, vino nobile di Montepulciano, and brunello di Montalcino).
  - **Other Regions**: Umbria and Emilia-Romagna in Italy; limited production in California.
- **Genetics and Variations**:
  - **DNA Research (2004)**: Identified one parent of Sangiovese as being from southern Italy (Calabrese di Montenuovo).
  - **Varietal Complexity**: Variations in clones (hundreds to thousands) due to genetic instability.
- **Soil and Style Variance**: Depending on the quality of the soil, Sangiovese wines can vary from poor (dry and dreary) to excellent (earthy, rich, and complex).
- **Traditional Pairing**: Best combined with peppery extra virgin olive oil due to its earthy and rich flavor profile.

This summarizes the detailed points mentioned in the document about Riesling and Sangiovese wines.

#### Description of Tannin:
- **Nature and Impact**: Tannin is an essential wine component primarily associated with red wines. It's recognized for its ability to influence the wine's astringency, which often results in a mouth-drying sensation. Despite this, tannin is indispensable in the wine-making process, contributing to the wineâ€™s structure, aging potential, and overall quality. It is known for imparting complex flavors which might be bitter, harsh, or coarse.
- **Source**: Tannins are derived from the skins, seeds, and stems of red grapes, and smaller quantities from oak barrels used during the aging process.
- **Benefits**: Tannin contributes to the wine's velvety texture and aging capability. Additionally, tannins have health benefits linked to compounds found in them.

# Tandoori-Style Shrimp

**Serves:** 4

**Recommended with:** For floral, peach-flavored, distinctly off-dry (slightly sweet) Rieslings

## Ingredients

### Marinade
- 1 cup nonfat plain yogurt
- 2 jalapeÃ±o chilies (leave seeds in for extra heat), chopped
- 3 tablespoons fresh lemon juice
- 2 large cloves garlic, chopped
- 2-inch piece of peeled fresh ginger, sliced thinly across the grain
- 1 tablespoon ground cumin
- Â½ teaspoon salt
- Â¼ teaspoon turmeric
- 1Â½ pounds large shrimp, shelled and deveined
- 1 tablespoon sweet paprika
- Lime or lemon wedges

## Instructions

1. **Preparation:**
   - Place the yogurt, jalapeÃ±os, lemon juice, garlic, ginger, cumin, salt, and turmeric in the container of a food processor and pulse to combine.
   - Place the shrimp in a large nonaluminum container.
   - Add the marinade and toss to coat.
   - Marinate in the refrigerator for 1 hour.

2. **Cooking:**
   - Soak bamboo skewers in water for 30 minutes.
   - Preheat the broiler or prepare a charcoal or gas grill.
   - Thread the shrimp on two parallel bamboo skewers for easy turning.
   - Broil or grill until pink and firm, turning once, about 2 minutes per side.

3. **Serving:**
   - Sprinkle with paprika and serve with lime wedges.

## Variation
- If the budget is tight, fish cubes can be substituted for shrimp. This marinade is also excellent for boneless chicken breasts, cut into cubes and skewered. Chicken can marinate for 4 to 5 hours, fish, and shrimp need only a 1-2 hour marinade, as the yogurt and citrus have a tenderizing effect.

### ASIAN RICE ALCOHOLS

#### Wheat Beers
German wheat beers are distinct because:
- A large fraction of barley malt is replaced by wheat malt.
- They produce a more foamy and hazy brew.
- They develop more tartness and fruitiness.
- They utilize an unusual yeast (Torulaspora) that produces aroma compounds not usually found in beer.

These beers are often called:
- **Weizen** for â€œwheat.â€
- **Weizenbier** for â€œyeast-wheat.â€
- **Weissbier** for â€œwhite.â€

American breweries are also producing wheat beers similar to the German model, described as mild, tart, and cloudy.
  
#### Belgian Lambic Beers
- Brewers are highly inventive, allowing diverse microbes to participate in the fermentation process.
- Some beers are fermented for years, and occasionally spices, herbs, or fruits are added to create hybrid beers or fruit wines.
- Aged hops are used for less bitterness and higher aromatic, astringent properties.
- The most unusual Belgian beers are the **lambics**, known for a long, spontaneous fermentation in wood barrels, which lends unique characteristics.
  
#### Asian Rice Alcohols:
1. **Chinese Chiu**
2. **Japanese Sake**

### Sweet Moldy Grains
- In eastern Asia, a distinct alcohol known for its high alcohol content (up to 20%) is made from starchy grains using mold to supply the starch-digesting enzymes, instead of allowing the grains to convert sugars to alcohol directly as in typical brewing processes.

Here's the content structured in Markdown format, including translations of the French terms to English for clarity: ### 3.1 Sensory Analysis #### Diapo x: Gustatory Examination #### Other Gustatory Sensations Additional gustatory sensations that can appear during tasting: | Sensations | Characteristics | |------------|-----------------| | **Tannins** | - Solid elements of the wine (mostly red wine) that constitute the "body" of the wine, its structure, and firmness
- They provide relief and a tactile sensation on the tongue compared to a velvety wine
- A lower temperature exacerbates the hardness of the tannins and the astringent side | | **Astringency** | - Causes mouth and gums dryness, as well as a rough sensation (mouth puckering)
- Related to the presence of overly young or poor-quality tannins | | **Fat** | - Gives a viscous character to the wine
- Helps soften overly harsh tannins in a robust red wine by enveloping them
- For white wines, a fatty side reveals malolactic fermentation (transformation of malic acid into lactic acid) | | **Sparkling** | - Presence of CO2 bubbles released by alcoholic fermentation
- Sought after in calm wines to provide a bit of freshness in very hot years like 2003
- In a sparkling wine (crÃ©mant), look for the finesse and persistence of the bubbles | | **Pseudo-thermal Sensations** | - Can feel different even if the wines are served at the same temperature
- Sensation of heat often associated with a prominent presence of alcohol (ethanol)
- Sensation of coolness due to mentholated, eucalyptus, acidic elements or sparkling (CO2) | The content systematically explores the different types of sensations that might be distinguished during the gustatory examination of wines, offering a deeper understanding of the complex interactions within wine tasting.

# Understanding Wines: Explaining Style and Quality

## Fungal Diseases
### Grey rot
- **Caused by:** _Botrytis cinerea_
- **Conditions:** Thrives in damp
- **Effects:** 
  - Can taint grapes, causing loss of color in black grapes.
  - In certain conditions, can be beneficial as it helps to produce some of the finest sweet wines in the world.
- **Potential Benefit:** Botrytis cinerea infection can be beneficial (referred to as _noble rot_).
- **Note:** More details in Section called Wine making in Chapter 8.

### Control Methods
- **Traditional:** Use of chemical sprays (fungicides).
- **Current Trends:** 
  - Reduced use of fungicides.
  - Spraying mostly done by tractor.
  - Aim for no harmful chemical residues in wine.
- **Advancements:**
  - Improved canopy management.
  - Example of practices: Advanced aeration techniques that reduce canopy climate's humidity and moisture.

### Other Diseases
#### Viruses
- **Impact:** Do not kill the vine, but limit the vine's ability to function effectively.
- **Transmission:** Commonly spread via cuttings or nematodes.
- **Control:** Can only be managed by sanitizing the land and uprooting infected vines.

#### Bacterial diseases
- **Caused by:** Different bacteria, spread by insects like sharpshooters.
- **Effects:** Reduce grape quality and quantity.
- **Control:** No treatments or cures; control involves interrupting the lifecycle of the sharpshooters.

## Viticultural Practices
- Until the late 20th century, common practice involved the use of man-made chemicals to control pests in vineyards.

## Sustainable Agriculture
- **Principles:** Does not prohibit the use of man-made chemicals but encourages integrated pest management.
- **Focus:** Develop a deep understanding of the lifecycle of vineyard pests to better predict and prevent damage.
- **Approach:** Follow a regimented calendar of spraying, reducing the total applications needed.
- **Goal:** Minimize the use of pesticides to sustain natural predators and biodiversity.

## Organic Agriculture
- **Principles:** Similar to sustainable agriculture but stricter.
- **Requirements:** Must adhere to certification standards to be labeled as organic.
- **Certification:** Granted by various organizations, standards vary by region.

## Biodynamic Agriculture
- **Foundation:** Based on principles by Rudolf Steiner and Maria Thun.
- **Practices:** Involves comprehensive organic practices and connections between the vineyard and broader ecosystem.

### Impact of Pesticides and Environmental Concerns
- **Historical Concern:** Increased resistance of pests to chemicals.
- **Environmental Impact:** Damage by chemical sprays in vineyards has led to worries among growers, consumers, and legislations seeking to reduce chemical applications.

### Conclusion
The transition towards more sustainable, organic, and biodynamic practices illustrates a shift in the wine industry towards environmental responsibility and enhanced wine quality through natural growth practices.

The document discusses various methods and ingredients used in making kombucha, highlighting the flexibility and variation possible in this process. Here's a structured summary of the content presented in the document:

1. **Sweeteners Variability**:
   - Some kombucha recipes utilize honey, agave, maple syrup, barley malt, fruit juice, and other sweeteners.
   - Others achieve good results without using any tea, substituting with herbal infusions or fruit juices.

2. **Adaptability of Kombucha Cultures**:
   - Kombucha cultures ("mothers") vary in their adaptability to different conditions and sweeteners.
   - Encouragement to experiment with various sweeteners and flavorings, but advised to retain one traditional SCOBY layer using standard sugar and tea as a control.

3. **Preparation Recommendations**:
   - Utilize a single layer of traditional SCOBY during experiments.
   - For new batches, mix sugar (approximately Â½ cup or 125 ml by weight, approximately 4 ounces or 113 g) per quart/liter of tea.
   - Ensure sugar dissolves completely in hot tea before adjusting to preferred sweetness.

4. **Tea Cooling and Fermentation Set-Up**:
   - Cool the sweetened tea below body temperature to prepare for fermentation.
   - Suggestion to make a tea concentrate and dilute with cold water to speed up cooling.
   - Use a wide-mouth fermentation vessel made of glass or ceramic; avoid using metal vessels.

5. **Initial Fermentation Steps**:
   - After cooling, add mature kombucha to the sweetened tea, maintaining a ratio of about 5 to 10 percent of the tea volume.
   - This addition both acidifies the tea and introduces kombucha organisms.

### Key Points from the Document:

1. **Role of Fruits in Fermentation**:

   - Fruits and fruit juices can spontaneously ferment into primarily alcohol and, if exposed to air, into acetic acid rather than lactic acid.
   - It discusses different methods of fruit fermentation, referencing "Chapter 4" for methods related to fermenting fruit into alcohol.
   
3. **Combination of Fruits and Vegetables**:
   - Mixes of fruits with vegetables generally contain both yeasts and lactic acid bacteria.
   - In the case of "fruit kimchi," when mixed with salted and spiced vegetables, fruits ferment into alcohol and acetic acid, while the vegetables primarily ferment into lactic acid.
   - Fruit kimchi, if still somewhat sweet, is recommended to be refrigerated after just a few days of fermentation.

4. **Influencing Factors in Yeast Activity**:
   - Yeast activity can be diminished by heavy salting or addition of lactic acid starter cultures like whey.

   - A popular lactic acid fermented fruit product is salted lemons and limes.

### Cooking Fish and Shellfish

#### Cooking Methods

- **Simmering, Poaching, Stewing:**

  - Benefits: Fish can be flavored in many ways and served with portions of its cooking liquid, complemented with other ingredients. French call it **"Ã  la nage"** or **"aswim."**

#### Cooking Liquids for Fish:

- **General Advice:**
  - Fish requires minimal cooking, promoting little exchange of flavors as it does not need to mellow with other ingredients.
  - Typically uses simple liquids designed to be discarded or repurposed (e.g., fish stocks).

- **Types of Cooking Liquids:**
  - **Salted Water, Vinegar, Wine:** Basics for court bouillon or other simple broths.
  - **Milk:** Optionally mixed with water for a richer flavor.
  - **Court Bouillon:** A mix of water, salt, wine or vinegar, vegetable aromatics, often simmered for 30â€“60 minutes.

#### Fish Stocks:

- **Fumets:**
  - Description: Stocks made from simmered fish bones, with or without vegetables and herbs.
  - Details: Developed in French cuisine, fumets are rich in gelatin and deteriorate quickly.

#### Preparations Using Fish Liquids:

- **Clarified Stocks:**
  - Technique: Involves clarifying with egg whites and fish proteins to remove impurities.
  - Result: A translucent and flavorful basis for other dishes like consommÃ©.

- **Emulsion Sauces:**
  - Examples: Beurre blanc and beurre montÃ©.

#### Fish Aspics:

- **General Concept:**
  - Description: ConsommÃ©s fortified with gelatin to create a firm, sliceable texture.
  - Additional Ingredient: Commercial gelatin, or fish gelatin which melts at a lower temperature (about 77Â°F/25Â°C) for a more delicate texture.

### WHERE AND HOW SHOULD I STORE WINE?

The ancient Greeks mixed wine with honey (sugar acts as a preservative), poured olive oil on top of it (as a barrier to air), and stored it in large ceramic amphorae buried in the ground to keep the wine cool. For thousands of years, wine lovers have been motivated to store wine in a way that keeps it as wine, rather than expensive vinegar.

By the sixteenth century, much of the wine traded throughout Europe was high in alcohol and further fortified with brandy to preserve it. The base wine itself may have come from any warm place along the Mediterranean, from southern Spain to Crete. In many cases, the origin did not matter; what was important was that the raw wine be fortified sufficiently that it would still be drinkable when it reached England, Ireland, or northern Europe. Any wine that was not fortified was drunk immediately. These young, fresh wines were highly desirable. For most of history, in fact, young wine was always more expensive than old. Intentionally storing wine to age it came into practice only after the eighteenth century, when bottles came into widespread use. When aged in a bottle with a tight-fitting cork, wine not only did not turn to vinegar, but some of it actually improvedâ€”sometimes markedly so, especially if it was red. For the first time, certain older wines began to command a higher price than young wines. And â€œlaying a wine downâ€ to better it began to take on sophisticated connotations.

Corkâ€”the historic closure for wineâ€”is a miraculous material. But the 20th century gave us an additional asset: well-made, expensive screw caps.

The legacy remains. Aging a wine still seems like the right thing to do with a moderately expensive wine, even though the fact that most modern wine is actually not meant to be aged for long periods of time. Virtually all white wines and rosÃ© wines are made to be drunk fresh and young. Even among red wines, only those with firm structure and impeccable balance are meant for the long haul. The French make a distinction.

The document titled "PDO, PGIâ€“THE EUROPEAN UNION WINE LAWS," discusses the complexities of wine-producing laws in the European Union and certain national laws that exist simultaneously within the member states, focusing particularly on France, Italy, and Spain. Below is a structured summary of the document:

1. **EU and National Wine Laws**
   - **Context**: Each wine-producing country in Europe has specific national designations for wine, such as France's Appellation dâ€™Origine ContrÃ´lÃ©e (AOC) and Italy's Denominazione di Origine Controllata (DOC). 
   - **Introduction of EU Laws**: In 2009, the European Union introduced its own set of wine laws that apply to all member countries, including major wine producers like France, Italy, and Spain.

2. **Main EU Wine Designations**
   - **PDO (Protected Designation of Origin)**: This labeling is used for wines that are produced, processed, and prepared in a specific geographical area, and whose quality or properties are significantly or exclusively determined by the geographical environment.
   - **PGI (Protected Geographical Indication)**: This designation allows wineries to use either their national labels or the PGI designation from the EU. For example, wines from the Bordeaux or Champagne areas can use either the French AOC or the EU PGI labels.

3. **Usage and Impact of These Designations**
   - **French Wineries**: They have the choice to label wines under commonly known national terms (e.g., *vin de pays*) or the newer EU terms like PGI.
   - **Adaptations**: The term PGI, abbreviated from the French *Indication GÃ©ographique ProtÃ©gÃ©e*, is gaining preference, and the use of traditional terms like *vin de pays* is now accompanied by the mandatory use of the PGI logo on labels.

4. **Goals of EU Regulations**
   - **Protection and Unification**: The EU aims to provide consumer protection and a unified labeling system that clearly identifies the quality and origin of wines. The EU system incorporates older systems like AOC and DOC and adds new categories like PDO and PGI.

5. **Cultural Impact and Global Influence**
    - **Historical Context**: French wines, often from renowned estates and chÃ¢teaux, have been exported globally since the 17th century, influencing wine production in regions including South Africa, the Americas, New Zealand, and Australia.

6. **Future Content**
    - The document mentions that it will explore France's most important wine regions in subsequent sections, suggesting a detailed look at the significance and hierarchy of these regions, possibly evaluating areas like Bordeaux, Champagne, and Burgundy.

This document not only elucidates the regulatory landscape for wine labeling within the European Union but also emphasizes the global cultural influence and historical significance of wine production, particularly in France.

The document titled "Maladies dues Ã  un insecte" (Diseases caused by an insect) discusses various types of insect-induced diseases affecting plants, specifically focusing on the symptoms and causal agents. Here's a structured breakdown of the content:

### Maladies dues Ã  un insecte

1. **La cicadelle**
   - Description: This pest is feared by vine growers as it is a vector of the golden yellowing disease, a quarantine disease that can lead to the uprooting of plants.

2. **La cochylis**
   - Description: A moth colored yellow straw with golden reflections. It undergoes four life stages: eggs, caterpillars, chrysalids, and adult insects.

3. **L'eudÃ©mis**
   - Description: A type of lepidopteran. The caterpillars of the second and third generations pierce grape grains, promoting grey rot and other secondary rot.

4. **La pyrale**
   - Description: A nocturnal moth. Eggs laid on the leaf will lead to caterpillars that attack the tender and herbaceous parts of plants.

5. **L'altise**
   - Description: A small beetle, whose larvae attack the leaves.

### Autres maladies (Other diseases)

1. **La chlorose**
   - Description: Discoloration of leaves turning yellow-green with an increasingly paler tone.

2. **Le millerandage**
   - Description: Small and large grains mix in a cluster because not all grains in a grape are fertilized at the same time.

3. **La coulure**
   - Description: It occurs when the flowers of the vine drop off without the fruits being replaced by grains. 

This document serves as an informational resource about certain plant diseases, providing critical insights into the identification and understanding of symptoms associated with various insect pests and other conditions.

### Ingredients
- **Butter**: 2 tablespoons
- **Cognac**: Â¼ cup
- **Kosher salt**
- **Freshly ground white pepper**
- **Curly parsley**: Â½ cup, chopped

### Preparation

1. **Starting the dish**:
   - Heat the oil in a pot over medium heat. Add the ginger and shallots and cook, stirring occasionally, until brown.
   - Add the mussels and saffron.
   - Add water and white wine.
   - Once the mussels open, remove them from the broth and set aside.
   - Discard non-opening mussels.
   - Add cognac to the broth, reduce by half, and keep warm on low heat.
   - Remove mussels from their shells, discard shells, and reserve.
   - Before serving, add butter and beat the reserved broth with an emulsion blender until frothy.
   - Adjust seasoning with salt, pepper, and curly parsley.

### Fish Preparation

- **Coriander seeds**: 1 teaspoon, toasted and ground
- **Cumin seeds**: 1 teaspoon, toasted and ground
- **Turmeric**: Â½ teaspoon
- **Curry powder**: 1 teaspoon
- **Monkfish**: 1Â½ pounds, trimmed and cut into Â½-inch cubes, season with kosher salt and freshly ground white pepper
- **Vegetable oil**: 2 tablespoons, neutral type

2. **Cooking the fish**:
   - Combine the coriander seeds, cumin, turmeric, and curry powder.
   - Coat the monkfish pieces in this spice mixture and season with salt and pepper.
   - In a skillet, heat the vegetable oil over medium-high heat and sautÃ© the fish until golden and cooked evenly on all sides, about 4 minutes.

### Plating

- Spoon the monkfish and mussels into four bowls.
- Ladle the broth around the seafood.
- Garnish each plate with a dollop of aioli and serve with additional croutons and remaining aioli.

### Taste Notes

- The dish features various textures of seafood (soft mussels and toothy monkfish).
- The combination of saffron, curry, and coriander results in a strong, well-rounded flavor enhanced by garlic.
- Aioli emulsion adds smoothness and a rounded mouthfeel to the dish.

# COMMON FRUITS OF TEMPERATE CLIMATES

### Types of Apples:

#### 1. Cider Apples
- **Example**: European native *Malus sylvestris*
- **Characteristics**: High-acid fruits rich in astringent tannins. These tannins help control the alcoholic fermentation and clarify the liquid.
- **Uses**: Mainly used only in cider making.

#### 2. Dessert or Eating Apples
- **Characteristics**: Crisp and juicy with a pleasing balance between sour and sweet when eaten raw. They become relatively bland when cooked.
- **Common in**: Supermarkets and produce markets as dessert apples.

#### 3. Cooking Apples
- **Characteristics**: Distinctly tart when raw and well-balanced when cooked. They maintain structure well when heated in pies or tarts. Some early "codling" varieties turn into a fluffy froth.
- **Notable Varieties**: 
  - France: *Calville blanc dâ€™hiver*
  - England: *Bramleyâ€™s Seedling*
  - Germany: *Glockenapfel*

#### 4. Dual-purpose Apples
- **Characteristics**: Adequate either raw or cooked; best when young and tart, mellows as it ages.
- **Examples**: 
  - *Golden Delicious*
  - *Granny Smith*

### Cooking Potential of Apples:
- Can be tested by wrapping a few slices in aluminum foil and baking at a hot oven for 15 minutes, or microwaving till the covering bloats.

### Apple Flavor Development:
- **Connoisseurship**: Noted by Edward Bunyard on the evolution of flavor post-harvest.
- **Storage**: Best stored in a cool and dry place and inspected periodically to catch volatile ethers at their developmental peak.
- **Aging**: Apples mellow with time because they consume some of their cell acid for energy.

### Fruit Aroma Compounds: Esters

Many fruits develop their aroma from esters, which are a combination of an acid and an alcohol. Here are some examples of ester aroma compounds in fruits:

- Ethyl alcohol + Acetic acid = Ethyl acetate (common in apples)
- Hexyl alcohol + Acetic acid = Hexyl acetate (common in pears)
- Ethyl alcohol + Butyric acid = Ethyl butyrate (common in pineapple)
- Isoamyl alcohol + Acetic acid = Isoamyl acetate (common in bananas)

The document provides a detailed overview of the wine regulations in Spain, particularly focusing on the DenominaciÃ³n de Origen (DO) and DenominaciÃ³n de Origen Calificada (DOCa) classifications. Here's the structured content of the document:

### Spain's Wine Classification Systems

1. **DenominaciÃ³n de Origen (DO)**:
   - Similar to Franceâ€™s Appellation d'Origine ContrÃ´lÃ©e laws.
   - Enacted in 1932 and revised since.
   - Provides rules that protect regionally specific wines and enforce standards.

2. **DenominaciÃ³n de Origen Calificada (DOCa)**:
   - Higher classification than DO.
   - Requires wines to have demonstrated high quality over a long time.
   - Regions must have DO status for at least ten years.
   - Example regions: Rioja and Priorat.

3. **Consejo Regulador**:
   - Governing control board for each DO and DOCa.
   - Sets viticultural and winemaking standards.
   - Oversees acreage, types of grapes planted, the total wines produced.
   - Maintains a laboratory and tasting panel.

4. **Other Classifications**:
   - **Pago**: A status for estates with special merit, more stringent than DOCa.
   - **Vino de Pago**: Designation for wines from recognized estates that meet specific conditions and have an international reputation for quality.
   - First to receive Pago status was Dominio de Valdepusa.

5. **Labeling Requirements**:
   - Wines must display the variety, and at least 85% of the wine should be from the variety named.

6. **Aging Categories in Wine Labeling**:
   - **Vino de Crianza**: Red wines aged minimum 24 months, 6 in oak. Whites and rosÃ©s: 18 months.
   - **Reserva**: Red wines aged minimum 36 months, 12 in bottle. Whites and rosÃ©s: 18 months, 6 in oak.

The document provided details two main topics discussed in separate sections:

### Butter Preparation

1. **Description**: It explains how to make butter by agitating cream in a jar, a food processor, or a bowl with a spoon. The process takes about 5 to 10 minutes and involves the butterfats clumping together to form solid butter, leaving behind liquid buttermilk.
2. **Process**:
   - Agitate cream until butter forms.
   - Drain off buttermilk and place butter in refrigerator to harden slightly.
   - Consume the fresh buttermilk or continue to process the butter by rinsing it in cold water, kneading, and repeating the rinse until the water runs clear.
   - Allow the butter to air dry and store it either in or out of the refrigerator to develop fermented flavors.

### Whey

1. **Definition**: Whey is described as the thin liquid that remains after milk solidifies and curdles, often through acidification.
2. **Uses and Misconceptions**:
   - Sally Fallon, author of *Nourishing Traditions*, recommends whey as a starter for various ferments, ranging from vegetables to sodas.
   - Common misconceptions about whey involve its content and use, as some confuse whey protein powder with liquid whey, leading to failed fermentation attempts.
3. **Composition**:
   - Whey is rich in protein and has most of the milk fats removed.
   - It is commonly used by bodybuilders and those requiring concentrated protein sources.
   - Whey is often dried into a powder form, which retains some active cultures depending on the process.

The text underlines practical applications and common misunderstandings associated with dairy products in homemade culinary practices.

Below is the structured content extracted from the provided document page regarding "EDIBLE PLANTS":

---

**Page 264: EDIBLE PLANTS**

**1. Introduction of Leaf Structure and Function:**

- Leaves are the most fragile and short-lived parts of the plant, designed to maximize light capture.
- They are flattened into thin sheets with a large surface area densely packed with chloroplasts and filled with thousands of tiny air pockets, increasing the exposure to air.
- Some leaves have up to 70% of their volume made up of air, helping them shrink when cooked due to the collapse of their spongy interior.

**2. Exception to the Storage issue in Bulb Ornaments:**
  
- Plants like the onion family store nutrients in leaves, with multiple layers of cells that can thicken and support the plant.
- The base of the leaf bases, especially in bulbs like onions and garlic, can store water which gets used in subsequent years of growth.

**3. Flowers as Reproductive Organs:**

- Flowers are reproductive structures where male pollen and female ovules are produced, leading to the development of seeds.
- While flowers are often colorful to attract pollinators, some protect their flowers and are typically used as culinary ingredients (broccoli, cauliflower, artichokes, etc.).

**4. Fruit Development:**
  
- Fruits are derived from the flowerâ€™s ovary and contain seeds.
- They are designed to disperse seeds away from the parent plant, and although some are inedible when immature, the ones we eat develop flavors and nutritional content.

**5. Texture of Raw Fruits and Vegetables:**

- Describes how fruits and vegetables are juicy and soft, or could be mealy, dry, or chewy depending on their cell construction and water content.

**6. Cellular Structure of Plant Tissues:**

- Plant tissues are constructed with cell walls made from cellulose fibers and a semisolid mixture containing carbohydrates, proteins, and minerals.
- These components provide structural integrity and contribute to the texture.

**7. Role of Water in Crispness and Firmness:**

- Discusses how cells use water as a reinforcing element within their structures, allowing fruits and vegetables to maintain a crisp texture.
- When a plantâ€™s cell reaches maximum water capacity, it becomes firm and crisp, relying on the surrounding cement-like semisolid materials.

---

### RECOMMENDED BOTTLES

**Carpano Antica Formula Vermouth:** This sweet vermouth is equally delicious on its own as it is mixed into a cocktail. Its bitter, full-bodied flavor profile includes cocoa, orange, caramel, and figs, along with a big vanilla note. In cocktails it's a versatile modifier that can both complement and contrast with other flavors, though it can sometimes be a bully in the glass compared to other vermouths. There was a time when we were putting Carpano in everything, especially any variation on the Manhattan. Those were the days when Death & Co was defining â€œstirred and bitterâ€ as a category. Since then weâ€™ve mellowed a bit to include other vermouths.

**Cocchi Vermouth di Torino:** Like Carpano Antica (to which it is stylistically similar), this sweet vermouth has a strong vanilla note and a rich, compelling body, but unlike Carpano it lets other ingredients shine through in cocktails.

**Dolin Blanc Vermouth:** With its full body and sweetness, Dolin blanc works like a red vermouth and pairs well with base spirits that would overpower a dry vermouth, especially blanco tequila. We reach for this when introducing guests to stirred, boozy drinks, as it lightens the intensity of the drink without masking other flavors.

**Dolin Dry Vermouth:** This beautiful, soft, dry vermouth has gentle herbaceous flavors and a touch of sweetness. It pairs nicely with subtly flavored base spirits by stretching out their flavors and is the base ingredient in Alex's Aperitivo Julep.

**Dolin Rouge Vermouth:** Made from wine and botanicals from ChambÃ©ry, France, Dolin rouge is drier and lighter bodied than Carpano Antica or Cocchi Torino, which makes it too wimpy to stand up to bigger brown spirits (unless weâ€™re making a Manhattan with a wheat-heavy bourbon; then itâ€™s just right). To remedy this, we mix equal parts Dolin rouge and Punt e Mes to make our House Sweet Vermouth.

**Punt e Mes:** This very poignant sweet vermouth is almost amaro-like in its sharp taste.

It categorizes cheeses into seven types based on texture, flavor, and wine compatibility. These categories are detailed with descriptions and examples as follows:

### Cheese Categories:
1. **Fresh**
   - Description: Unripened and unaged cheeses like ricotta, mozzarella, and feta.
   - Characteristics: Versatile and mild flavor.

2. **Semi-Soft**
   - Description: Cheeses that give a bit when squeezed; examples include teleme and Havarti.
   - Characteristics: They soften as they ripen, higher salt content and edible fuzzy rind. 

3. **Soft-Ripened**
   - Description: Cheeses that soften rather than harden as they age.
   - Examples: Brie and Camembert.
   - Characteristics: Higher moisture content with an edible rind.

4. **Semi-Hard**
   - Description: Balanced salt and fat, very flexible cheeses.
   - Examples: Basic Cheddar to Gouda.
   - Characteristics: Range from buttery to nutty flavors, includes interpretations like Emmentaler and ComtÃ©.

5. **Hard**
   - Description: Often sharp and quite firm cheeses.
   - Examples: Parmesan, aged Cheddar, and dry Jack.
   - Characteristics: Salty and ideal for shaving.

6. **Blue**
   - Description: Identified by blue or green mold.
   - Examples: Gorgonzola to Roquefort.
   - Characteristics: Salty and strong flavor, from mild sweetness to intense dolce.

7. **Washed-Rind**
   - Description: Often known as the â€œstinky socksâ€ category since these cheeses are washed with brine, wine or brandy during the ripening process.
   - Examples: Taleggio, Munster, and Ã‰poisses.
   - Characteristics: Smell stronger than they taste, edible but strong rind that is often off-putting to some.

### THE HISTORY OF SAUCES IN EUROPE

Europe is one of several regions in the world that have evolved sauces with broad appeal in modern times. Many sauces are now popular far from their birthplaces, among them Chinese soy-based sauces, Indian sauces thickened and flavored with spices, and Mexican salsas and chili-thickened moles. But it was in Europe, more precisely in France, that generations of cooks developed sauce making into a systematic art, and made it the heart of a national cuisine that became an international standard.

#### ANCIENT TIMES

Our first real knowledge of sauce-like preparations in Europe comes from Roman times. A Latin poem from around 25 CE describes a peasant farmer making a spread of pounded herbs, cheese, oil, and vinegarâ€”an ancestor of pesto genoveseâ€”that gave a pungent, salty, aromatic savor to his flatbread (see box, p. 583).

A few centuries later, the Latin recipe book attributed to Apicius makes it clear that sauces played an essential part in the dining of the Roman elite. More than a quarter of the nearly 500 recipes are for sauces, the term for which was ius, the ancestor of our â€œjuice.â€ Most contained at least a half dozen herbs and spices, as well as vinegar and/or honey, and some form of the fermented fish sauce garum (p. 235), which provided saltiness, savoriness, and a distinctive aroma (much as anchovies do today). And they were thickened in a variety of ways: with the pounded flavorings themselves; with pounded nuts or rice; with pounded liver or sea urchins; with pounded bread, pieces of pastry, and with pure wheat starch itself; with egg yolks, both raw and boiled.

### Harmonizing Flavors in Ancient China

The addition, intensification, and blending of flavors that characterize good sauce making are central to the art of cooking, and have been considered such for at least 2,000 years. Here is an ancient Chinese description of the process that centers on the making of a stew or soup, a preparation in which the solid food both provides part of the sauce and cooks in the sauce.

In the business of harmonious blending, one must make use of the sweet, sour, bitter, pungent and salty. Whether things are to be added earlier or later and in what amountsâ€”their balancing is very subtle and each thing has its own characteristic. The transformation which occurs in the cauldron is quintessential and wondrous, subtle and delicate. The mouth cannot express it in words; the mind cannot fix upon an analogy. It is like the subtlety of archery and horsemanship, the transformation of Yin and Yang, or the revolution of the four seasons. Thus [the food] is long-lasting yet does not spoil; thoroughly cooked yet not mushy; sweet yet not cloying; sour yet not corrosive; salty yet not deadening; pungent yet not acrid; mild yet not insipid; oily-smooth yet not greasy.

â€”attributed to the chef Yi Yin in the LÃ¼ Shi Chun Qiu (Master LÃ¼'s Spring and Autumn Annals), 239 BCE, transl. Donald Harper and H. T. Huang

The provided text seems to discuss the preparation and variants of traditional Indian dishes like idli, dosa, dhokla, and khaman. Below is the structured content of the document:

---

### Idli Preparation

- **Idli** is usually steamed using specially designed forms or an improvised steamer.
- The batter (fermented) is wrapped in corn husks similar to tamales and steamed for approximately 20 minutes.
- It is typically served with a spicy vegetable dal called **sambar**.
- For **dosa**, the batter should be much thinner compared to idli and needs to be spread as thin as possible on a well-oiled or non-stick pan.

### Dhokla and Khaman

- **Dhokla** differs from idli by using various legumes and being steamed in different forms.
- Typically made from dehulled Bengal gram dal and rice.
- A variant is mentioned involving chickpeas.
- After steaming, dhokla is cut into small squares for serving.
- It may be seasoned with mustard seeds fried in oil with asafoetida, then topped with coconut shreds and coriander leaves.

- **Khaman** is similar to dhokla, using no rice but only a batter of dehulled Bengal gram dal (or other legumes) mixed with water and salt.

### Dosa Variations (by Orese Fahey, New Mexico)

- Experimental dosa preparations involve:
  - Forbidden Rice to make a dark purple dosa.
  - Red dal for a pink dosa.
  - Risotto rice, yellow and white dal suggesting flexibility in ingredients.
- The recommended ratio for these dosas is 2 parts rice to 1 part dal.
- Additions such as chopped green chile, minced garlic, and diced onion have been incorporated to suit local tastes (New Mexico).

---

This document presents information about Bergamot oranges, highlighting their unique sensory and utilization characteristics. The content is structured into a main article and a table that describes ingredient pairings with bergamot orange. Below is a detailed breakdown of both sections:

### Main Article

**Header: Bergamot**

1. **Description and Sensory Profile:**
   - Bergamot oranges are notable for their "unmistakably lemon-orange aroma," but they also have "floral, rose-like notes" and a complex fragrance.
   - Upon deeper inhalation, scents of "underlying herbal, piney notes" can be detected.
   - The fruit is described as having an "unpalatably bitter, acidic taste" and is primarily cultivated for its essential oils. The bright green outer peel of the fruit is cold-pressed to extract its essence, which is clear and yellowish-green.
   - The oils are commonly utilized in liqueurs, perfumes, and other cosmetics.

2. **Uses and Applications:**
   - In their natural state, bergamot oranges are generally considered inedible but are intriguingly sour, adding a unique twist to cocktails, savory dishes, and pastries.
   - High-quality bergamot oils are extracted primarily in Southern Italy and are recognized under the Protected Designation of Origin (PDO) status within the European Union.

3. **Historical and Cultural References:**
   - Bergamot oil has a flavor comparable to some premium Chinese teas, particularly Fou Shou oolong tea. During the 18th and 19th centuries, it was fashionable in Europe to make Earl Grey tea more exclusive by adding a bit of bergamot oil.
   - It is suggested that Earl Grey tea was a blend given to the 2nd Earl Grey by a Chinese mandarin.

4. **Additional Notes:**
   - The bergamot is also related to the *Monarda* genus of North American plants, known for their aromatic foliage and used by Native American tribes.
   - Suggestions for culinary uses include a bergamot-scented vinaigrette and using bergamot to enhance flavors in desserts, dishes, and salads.

- **Nutritional Enhancement**: Mixed-culture sourdough is noted for increasing the available lysine content and reducing the presence of gluten.
  
### Basic Sourdough Starter Recipe
- **Initial Mixing**: Combine a small amount of flour and water in a bowl, add more to achieve a smooth, pourable, yet thick consistency.
- **Flour Type**: Rye flour is recommended for its fast action, but any grain flour can be used.
- **Water Quality**: Use dechlorinated water to avoid harming the natural yeasts and bacteria.
- **Maintenance**: Stir the mixture at least once a day until bubbles appear, then transition to feeding it with a high proportion of fresh flour regularly.

### Advanced Techniques and Variations
- **Water Variants**: Some people use water from boiling potatoes or starchy water from rinsing grains, fruits, or vegetables.
- **Additives**: Options include using fruit or vegetable skins, and fermenting beer foams.
- **Commercial Starters**: Some starters begin with a packet of yeast and evolve, or use starters obtained or bought from others.
- **Hands-On Approach**: Stirring with clean hands as a means of culturing.

### Key Takeaway
- **Simplicity**: Fundamentally, the primary requirements for a sourdough starter are just flour and water. The rest of the techniques and additives are optional based on personal preference or specific desired characteristics of the sourdough.

---

### Recipe: Sweet Potato Makgeolli

**Source Reference:**
- Inspired by a blog called "Seoulful Cooking" which incorporates sweet potatoes, described as a favorite ingredient.

**Ingredients:**
- 2 pounds / 1 kg sweet rice
- Â½ pound / 250 g sweet potatoes (with skins)
- Minimum 1 gallon / 4 liters of dechlorinated water
- Crushed nuruk (a traditional Korean fermentation starter)

**Equipment Needed:**
- Bamboo steamers
- Cotton cloth
- Tray or cookie sheet
- Crock or large jar (at least 1 gallon / 4 liters capacity)
- Cloth for covering

**Instructions:**

1. **Preparation of Rice:**
   - Rinse the sweet rice and soak overnight (or all day).
   - Drain well and then steam the rice using bamboo steamers lined with a cotton cloth to prevent grains from falling through.

2. **Cooking Sweet Potatoes:**
   - Scrub the sweet potatoes and chop them into large chunks, leaving the skins on.
   - Steam the chopped sweet potatoes until soft.

3. **Mixing and Fermentation:**
   - Spread the cooked rice on a tray or cookie sheet to cool.
   - When the rice is cool enough to handle, transfer it to a large crock or jar.
   - Add about 2 quarts / liters of dechlorinated water.
   - Gently massage the rice to separate individual grains, then add the crushed nuruk.
   - Add the steamed sweet potatoes (skins included) to the rice mixture and crush them with your hands while mixing thoroughly.
   - Cover the mixture with a cloth and leave in a warm spot to ferment.

As depicted, the makgeolli is served or stored in a traditional pot, an image of which is included in the document. This method is noted for incorporating adaptations from various online resources and personal culinary tweaks regarding the use of sweet potatoes.

### A SURVEY OF COMMON VEGETABLES: Tomatoes

**General Information about Tomatoes:**
Tomatoes are rich in vitamin C and antioxidants, particularly lycopene, which is highly concentrated in tomato paste and ketchup.

**Tomato Anatomy and Flavor:**
- **Anatomy:**
  - Tomatoes generally consist of four main tissues:
    - Thin, tough cuticle or skin, sometimes peeled.
    - Outer fruit wall.
    - Semiliquid jelly and juice surrounding the seeds.
    - Wall tissue which contains most of the sugars and amino acids.
  - The concentration of acids is higher in the jelly and juice than in the wall.
  - Aroma compounds are primarily found in the cuticle and wall.
  
- **Flavor Preparation Method:**
  - Often prepared by removing the skin, seeds, and jelly, which enhances their refined texture and alters the flavor balance towards sweetness, sacrificing some aroma.
  - Cooking tomatoes involves cooking the skins, jelly, and juice together until most of the liquid evaporates, then straining the remainder into the cooking tomato flesh. This process helps in restoring flavor lost due to evaporation.

**Types of Tomatoes:**
- **Ripe Tomatoes:** When allowed to ripen fully on the vine, tomatoes accumulate more sugar, acid, and volatile compounds, enhancing their flavor.
- **Unripe Tomatoes:** Often picked green and artificially stimulated to redden, leading typically to a less flavorful variety.
- **Regional Preferences:** Different regions prefer different textures and flavors:
  - In Europe and Latin America, less fruity, more vegetable-like mature green tomatoes are preferred.
  - In rural Peru, both tomato and tomatillo are appreciated even when they are frankly bitter.

**Cooked Tomatoes:**
- When cooked, the tomatoes lose some aromatic qualities but gain flavors from carotenoid pigments and other components.
- Notably, fresh-tomato leaves are sometimes added towards the end of cooking to reintroduce a fresh-tomato aroma attributed to leaf enzymes and aromatic oil glands.

**Figure Caption:**
- **Tomato Anatomy Illustration:**
  - Labels highlighting the jelly, pith, fruit wall, and the rich content of sugars, amino acids, and aroma molecules in the jelly and fruit wall, which are crucial for balancing the acids in tomatoes.

The document focuses on the role of hops in beer brewing. It is structured into categories that each discuss different aspects related to hops and various brewing methods. Here's an organized transcription and summary of the content:

### Bitterness and Aroma Hops
- **Bitterness**: Comes from phenolic "alpha acids" in their resins.
- **Aroma**: Derives from their essential oil. Some hop varieties are particularly valued for these properties.
- **Alpha acids**: Not very soluble in water, but prolonged boiling during brewing converts them into soluble structures that enhance beer flavor.
- **Volatile aroma compounds**: Some brewing processes involve adding hops after boiling to retain these aromatic qualities.
- **Character**: The aroma of typical hops is determined by myrcene (also found in bay leaf and verbena), and is woody and resinous. Noble hops are highlighted by their delicate aroma containing pine and citrus notes from terpenes like humulene and caryophyllene.

### Brewing Beer
- **Mashing**: Barley malt is soaked in hot water to convert starches into sugars.
- **Boiling**: Hops are added to the liquid, and the mixture is boiled to extract hop resins, kill microbes, and intensify the beer's flavor.
- **Fermentation**: Yeasts ferment the sugars to produce alcohol. This step continues until desired alcohol and flavor levels are achieved.
- **Conditioning**: The new beer is refined, aged, and carbonated.
- **Details**: Each stage has specific actions that are crucial for the final beer quality.

### Additional
- An illustration indicates details of the hop vine, Humulus lupulus, focusing on its female flower structure, the cone, particularly highlighting the "bracts" or clustered leaves that connect directly to oil glands, critical for imparting aroma and flavor in beer.

This document provides a concise explanation of how hops contribute to the beer's taste and aroma, as well as a brief overview of the beer brewing process.

The document appears to be a glossary of terms related to wine, primarily focused on those used in German and Austrian winemaking. Each entry defines a term related to the production, classification, or characteristics of wine. Below is the structured content of the document:

---

### K
- **Kabinett:** A level of minor sweetness in wine, previously common in Austria but now rarely seen outside specific ripeness designations like AUSBRUCH and BEERENAUSLESEN.
- **Keller:** German for cellar.
- **KMW:** Klosterneuburger Mostwaage scale, used in Austria to measure sugar in grapes. It is equivalent to OECHSLE in Germany, BAUME in France, and BRIX in the USA.

### L
- **Lese:** Term for harvest; varies from September to December, except for EISWEIN which is harvested in January.
- **Lieblich:** German term for wines with noticeable sweetness, sweeter than HALBTROCKEN, containing up to 4.5% residual sugar.

### O
- **Oechsle:** A scale measuring the ripeness of grapes in Germany.
- **Ortswein:** Indicates wines from good but not excellent vineyards in Germany, used by VDP members.

### P
- **PrÃ¤dikat:** Denotes "superior quality" or "special attributes," generally used for high-quality wines.

### Q
- **QualitÃ¤tswein bestimmter Anbaugebiete (QbA):** Everyday wine category in Germany from official wineregrowing regions, must be at least 7% alcohol by volume.
- **QualitÃ¤tswein mit PrÃ¤dikat (QmP):** Top level of German wines displaying a ripeness level required by label, ranging from dry to sweet. Unlike QbA, QmP cannot be chaptalized.

### R
- **Rotwein:** German for red wine, noting that both Germany and Austria primarily produce and consume white wines, but also produce quality red wines.

---

The document discusses the significance of "flor," specific strains of wild yeasts that thrive in Jerez and are crucial to the production of Sherry wine. Here's a structured summary of the content:

1. **Flor Definition**: 
   - Described as specific strains of wild yeasts found in Jerez.
   - Floats on the surface of the wine, contributing to Sherry's unique flavor.

2. **Metabolic Capabilities of Yeasts**:
   - These yeasts can consume both alcohol and oxygen.
   - The need for oxygen is partly why this yeast floats at the surface, allowing it to be closer to the air in the barrel.

3. **Environmental Contributions to Sherryâ€™s Unique Aspects**:
   - Sherry bodegas have large windows and are positioned facing the ocean to maximize sea breezes, enhancing yeast proliferation.
   - The yeasts emit acetaldehyde, a scent similar to nail polish remover but considered appealing in Sherry.

4. **Geographical Sensitivity**:
   - Flor yeast mutates or dies when moved from Jerez, meaning true Sherry cannot be replicated elsewhere, including regions like California, Chile, Italy, or even other parts of Spain.

5. **Role of Flor in Wine Oxidation**:
   - Flor yeast protects wine from oxidation by consuming surrounding oxygen.
   - It creates a protective layer on the wine, allowing minimal oxidation which adds complexity to the wine.

6. **Florâ€™s Importance in Making Fino and Manzanilla Varieties of Sherry**:
   - In Manzanilla, flor thrives in highly humid conditions, producing a wine with minimal exposure to oxidation.
   - Manzanilla is specifically made in the humid environment of SanlÃºcar de Barrameda, where conditions are uniquely suited for these yeasts.

This structured summary gives an overview of the importance and unique nature of flor yeasts in the production of Sherry, emphasizing its dependence on specific local environmental conditions.

This document section titled "Fish and Shellfish" from a book provides detailed descriptions on various aspects of marine culinary ingredients, specifically focusing on cephalopod texture and ink, other invertebrates like sea urchins, as well as methods of preserving fish.

### Cephalopod Texture
- **Detail**: The muscle fibers of squid and octopus are thin and fine-textured, arranged in multiple layers and significantly reinforced, giving their flesh a dense and tough quality. Unlike the collagen of fish, cephalopod collagen is extensively cross-linked and resembles that of abalone and other animals. To prevent toughening of the muscle fibers during cooking, they should be cooked briefly or cooked slowly to break down the collagen, softening it to a gelatinous texture.
- **Cooking Tips**: 
  - Squid and octopus should be cooked briefly to prevent muscle toughening or slow-cooked to dissolve the tougher collagen.
  - At temperatures around 130â€“135Â°F/55â€“57Â°C, the flesh is moist and tender.
  - At 140Â°F/60Â°C, the flesh curls and shrinks as collagen layers contract.

### Cephalopod Flavor and Ink
- **Features**: Cephalopods maintain their osmotic balance with tasteless trimethylamine oxide (TMAO) rather than free amino acids, resulting in a less sweet and more savory flavor compared to other molluscs. This can become fishy when bacteria convert TMAO into trimethylamine (TMA).
- **Cephalopod Ink**: This ink is a protective pigment that the animal can release when threatened; it contains heat-stable mix of phenolic compounds. Culinary uses include darkening stews and pastas.

### Other Invertebrates: Sea Urchins
- **Physical Description**: Sea urchins, part of the echinoderms family, have spiny exteriors and are known for their richly flavored reproductive tissues. They are valued for their golden, creamy insides, which account for a significant part of their biomass.
- **Usage**: 
  - In Japan, they are often eaten raw in sushi or seasoned.
  - In France, they are used in various cooked dishes including scrambled eggs, soufflÃ©s, and soups.

### Preserved Fish
- **Historical Context**: Before refrigeration and modern transportation, methods like drying, salting, smoking, fermenting, or other combinations of antimicrobial treatments were used for preserving fish.
- **Current Relevance**: Despite technology that allows for fresh fish, preserved fish continues to be crucial, especially in parts of Europe and Asia, offering not just a means of storage but also distinct flavors and textures.

### Dried Fish
- **Method**: Drying in the sun and wind was an ancient method of preserving fish, effective at reducing water content below 25% to restrict bacteria and mold growth.
- **Details**: This method ensures that while fresh fish contains water, lowering water content through sun-drying inhibits bacterial and mold growth, making the fish storable for longer periods.

## Sauternes and Barsac

Quite a bit south of Graves, along the Garonne River, are Bordeauxâ€™s five sweet-wine-producing communes, the two most important of which are Sauternes and Barsac (the other three are Bommes, Fargues, and Preignac). Sauternes and Barsac are not simply two unique, small places within Bordeaux; they are among the few regions in the world devoted to sweet wines. Sauternes, the more famous of the two, is about four times larger than tiny Barsac, but the wines from each can be extraordinary. At their best, these are wines with an apricotish opulence that detonates in your mouth and then spreads over your taste buds like liquefied honey. The British wine expert Hugh Johnson has described them best. Of one Sauternes, he wrote, â€œIt was glorious in its youth; a creamy, stinging, orange-scented, head-filling quintessence of pourriture noble. It is still awesome: now deep gold and smelling of crÃ¨me brÃ»lÃ©e, but still racily potent and endlessly sweet.â€

Needless to say, it takes merely a sip of a great Sauternes or Barsac to create a convert. The great examples are wonderful not because of their sweetness, however, but because of their extraordinary balance. The best are luscious without being cloying, richly honeyed without tasting like candy. To achieve this, the wines must have just the right acidity and alcohol and must be complex.

### How the Wine is Made

Sauternes and Barsac are made mostly from sÃ©millon and, to a lesser extent, sauvignon blanc grapes left on the vine well into the fall, whereupon they usually become infected with the benevolent fungus Botrytis cinerea, also known as pourriture noble or noble rot. SÃ©millon, the leading grape in the area, is especially susceptible to the fungus because of its large bunches of thin-skinned grapes with a high sugar content.

Graves is the only region of Bordeaux where almost every chÃ¢teau produces both a red and a white wine.

### Botrytis and Wine Quality

Although it seems unlikely that grapes left to decay into furry, moldy raisins will become magnificent wine, they can. In Sauternes and Barsac the process occurs naturally, though erratically, by virtue of the regionâ€™s singular climate. For the botrytis fungus to take hold on healthy, ripe grapes, the region must have just the right amount of humidity and warmth (too little or too much can produce problems). Sauternes and Barsac, the farthest south of all the important regions of Bordeaux, are ideally situated. Here, the Ciron River meets the Garonne River, creating gentle morning mists. If all goes well, nearby forests will help to hold the moisture in the air. When the day warms up and grows drier, a perfect stage is set for botrytis to appear.

As the beneficial mold punctures the grapesâ€™ skins in search of water to germinate its spores, the water begins to evaporate and the grapes dehydrate. Inside the shriveled berries, the sugar in the juice becomes progressively more concentrated. The botrytis also alters the structure of the grapesâ€™ acids, but the amount of acidity in the wine is not diminished.

### MEXICO

As an important wine region, Mexico may seem unlikely. Yet this is where the history of wine in the Americas began. Indeed, the first winery in the New Worldâ€”Casa Maderoâ€”was established in 1597 in the Mexican town of Santa Maria de las Parras (â€œHoly Mary of the Grapevinesâ€), and the winery continues to thrive today.

Like many wine drinkers, I once assumed that most Mexican wine would be cheap, rough-and-ready stuff sold in supermarkets. Admittedly, such wines do exist in Mexico (as they do nearly everywhere else). But beginning in the 1990s, and building on the success of already established wineries like Monte Xanic, Santo TomÃ¡s, and L.A. Cetto, a group of creative young winemakers quietly began making small lots of surprisingly delicious wines. Today, Mexicoâ€™s rapidly growing fine wine industry is bursting with energy, and the top wines are astonishing in quality.

Mexico has some 7,660 acres (3,100 hectares) of vineyards, and wine is produced in three principal areasâ€”in the northwest, specifically in the Baja Peninsula, immediately south of California; in the north central states of Coahuila, Durango, and Chihuahua, all just south of Texas and New Mexico; and in the center of Mexico, in the states of Zacatecas, Aguascalientes, and Queretaro. Of these three regions, more than 90 percent of all fine wine is produced in Baja.

The 1,012-mile-long (1,629-kilometer) Baja Peninsula is divided lengthwise by the mineral-rich Sierra de Baja California mountain range, which effectively divides the climate of the peninsula in half. All of the vineyards lie in arid valleys to the west of these mountains, where the climate is Mediterranean-like and cold air from the Pacific Ocean acts as a giant air conditioner, cooling the grapes. The main valleys extend, from the thriving port city of Ensenada on the Pacific Ocean. (A gastronomically oriented city, Ensenada is famous for its fish tacos, in which Pacific lobster or shark are deep-fried in lard, then wrapped in fluffy, homemade flour tortillas.)

The document primarily discusses the culinary uses of fennel pollen and lists various food items that pair well with it. The content can be structured into two main sections: a list of flavor affinities and a detailed description of Fennel Pollen.

### Flavor Affinities with Fennel Pollen

- Beef
- Boar
- Chicken
- Cream
- Fennel seeds
- Fish, especially flakier white, poached or steamed
- Garlic
- Lamb
- Lemon
- Nuts, especially almonds, pistachios

- Potatoes

- Rabbit
- Rice or risotto
- Salads
- Salmon
- Sea trout
- Shellfish
- Vegetables
- Yogurt

### Detailed Description of Fennel Pollen

Fennel pollen has a light, fennel-anise flavor with a floral component. It is described as being delicate, so it should be added at the end of cooking. It is particularly good on lighter dishes like salads, poached or steamed flaky white fish, poultry, or pork. When using fennel pollen, the aromatic and floral smell is noticeable even before tasting the food, enhancing thoughts of summer and freshness.

**Example Use Case in Cooking:**
Brad Farmerie, from PUBLIC (New York City), uses fennel pollen in a sea trout dish served with a simple salad of green apple, fennel, jicama, pistachios, and dried gooseberries. The dish is finished with fennel pollen, yogurt, lemon juice, and preserved lemon, enhancing the summer feel, especially when enjoyed with a glass of Sauvignon Blanc on a terrace in the early evening.

In general, fennel pollen is prized for its ability to add an herbaceous and mysterious flavor to various meats like pork, boar, chicken, and lamb, often used in marinades to impart these distinctive tastes.

### Recipe: Crunchy Sesame Shortbread Cookies
- **Yield**: Approximately 25 small cookies
- **Preparation time**: 15 minutes
- **Resting time**: 2 hours
- **Cooking time**: 12 to 15 minutes per batch

### Ingredients
- 110 g of soft butter
- 100 g of cane sugar
- 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract
- 160 g of flour
- 16 g of whole wheat flour (T110)
- Â¼ teaspoon of baking powder
- Â¼ teaspoon of salt
- 30 g of whole sesame seeds

### Instructions
1. **Creaming**:
   - Whip the butter with the sugar and vanilla extract using an electric mixer until you get a creamy mixture. Stop mixing when itâ€™s fully incorporated.

2. **Mixing dry ingredients**:
   - Mix the flour, whole wheat flour, baking powder, and salt. Gradually add the dry mix to the creamed mixture using a spatula until well combined.
   - Form into a ball, flatten slightly, and wrap in cling film. Chill in the refrigerator for 2 hours.

3. **Shaping and baking**:
   - Preheat the oven to 180Â°C (356Â°F).
   - Roll out the dough by hand, incorporating the sesame seeds into the dough as you roll.
   - Divide the dough onto two baking sheets lined with parchment paper. Flatten the cookies lightly.
   - Bake for 12 to 15 minutes, until the cookies are lightly cracked on the surface.
   - Let the cookies cool for 30 minutes before handling, as they are fragile when hot.

### Chefâ€™s Tips
- **Serving**: These cookies pair wonderfully with sorbet or tea.
- **Storage**: Can be stored for up to 1 week in an airtight container.

### Additional Notes
- The dough can be frozen for up to 2 months. Thaw in the refrigerator before rolling in sesame seeds and baking as described above.

## Wine and Food Pairing

### Ingredients and Styles

Sauvignon Blanc is considered one of the best wines to drink with food. Its ability to enhance a meal is praised, particularly when paired with most salads, light poultry, shellfish, and vegetarian dishes notable for bright, tangy flavors like peppers, eggplant, zucchini, asparagus, or leeks. It also beautifully complements most shellfish and simple seafood and fowl dishes. 

Meats like pork and veal, when paired with certain preparations that enhance their natural flavors using additions like citrus, capers, garlic, olives, and capers, also work well with Sauvignon Blanc. Dishes such as green salads with goat cheese, pasta with green beans, tomatoes, and garlic, and fish-fried rock fillets are all excellent counterparts.

Moreover, Sauvignon Blanc is notable for handling "small plates" or mezze-style dishes, providing balanced accompaniment without overpowering the dishes themselves. Ingredients such as feta, ricotta salata, Fontana, Jarlsberg, and any sheep cheese are recommended.

### Sauvignon Blends

Sauvignon blends that incorporate Semillon, Chardonnay, and Viognier adapt well to richer meal preparations like risotto, lightly smoked grilled white meat, fish, and poultry, and also handle fuller body and zippier acidity. They mirror the texture, personality, and main flavors of those dishes, resembling in some ways the strong personality found in aged white wines.

### Aged Sauvignon Blanc

Aged Sauvignon Blanc introduces different layers of taste, moving from tangy green and citrus notes to more developed flavors of nut, yellow and green vegetable, and sherry, especially for those with a palate for older wines, which can enhance more robust fish dishes, dishes with strong sauces, and textured vegetarian dishes (e.g., eggplant parmigiana or vegetarian lasagna).

### Methods of Cooking

In terms of cooking methods, Sauvignon Blanc is versatile with its ability to be paired with low-impact cooking methods which preserve the natural flavors of the ingredients. Its acidity enhances the dishes, especially steamed dishes which can be uplifted by the wineâ€™s characteristics.
